      <titleInfo>
         <title>Mishnayot Seder Tohorot</title>
         <subTitle>ʻim perushe...ʻOvadyah mi-Barṭenura ṿe-Tosfot YomṬov... ; im Tosafot ḥadashim me-... Shimshon me-Alṭona... ; hagahot... perushim... me-Yeshaý Berlin... niḳreu... Tosafot Rishon Le-Tsiyon</subTitle>
      </titleInfo>
      <titleInfo type="alternative">
         <title>Tosfot Yom Ṭov</title>
      </titleInfo>

      </titleInfo>

      <titleInfo>
         <title>Bulletin of the United States Geological and Geographical Survey of the Territories</title>
      </titleInfo>
      <titleInfo type="uniform">
         <title>Catalogue and index of the publications of the Hayden, King, Powell, and Wheeler surveys</title>
      </titleInfo>
      <name type="personal">
         <namePart>Hayden, F. V. (Ferdinand Vandeveer)</namePart>
         <namePart type="date">1829-1887</namePart>
      </name>
      <name type="corporate">
         <namePart>Geological and Geographical Survey of the Territories (U.S.)</namePart>
      </name>
      <typeOfResource>text</typeOfResource>
      <genre authority="fast">Periodicals.</genre>
      <genre authority="fast">Surveys.</genre>
      <originInfo>
         <place>
            <placeTerm authority="marccountry" type="code">dcu</placeTerm>
            <placeTerm authority="marccountry" type="text">District of Columbia</placeTerm>
         </place>
         <place>
            <placeTerm type="text">Washington</placeTerm>
         </place>
         <publisher>G.P.O.</publisher>
         <dateIssued>1874-</dateIssued>
         <dateIssued encoding="marc" point="start">1874</dateIssued>
         <dateIssued encoding="marc" point="end">1882</dateIssued>
         <issuance>serial</issuance>
         <frequency>Irregular</frequency>
         <frequency authority="marcfrequency">Completely irregular</frequency>
      </originInfo>
      <language>
         <languageTerm authority="iso639-2b" type="code">eng</languageTerm>
         <languageTerm authority="iso639-2b" type="text">English</languageTerm>
      </language>
      <physicalDescription>
         <form authority="marcform">print</form>
         <extent>6 v. : ill., plates (some folded), maps (some folded) ; 23 cm.</extent>
      </physicalDescription>
      <note type="statement of responsibility">Department of the Interior.</note>
      <note type="date/sequential designation">No. 1-2 (1874); second ser. [vol. 1], no. 1 (1875)-v. 6, no. 3 (1882).</note>
      <note>"F.V. Hayden, U.S. Geologist-in-charge."</note>
      <note type="numbering">"The first and second bulletins, which appeared in 1874, are separately paged pamphlets ... constituting a 'First Series' of the publication. Bulletins which appeared in 1875, being those of a 'Second series' and six in number, are continuously paged. With no. 6 were issued title, contents, index, &amp; c., for all the numbers of both 'series' which had then appeared; the design being that these should together constitute volume I, in order that the inconvenient distinction of 'series' might be dropped." Cf. v. 6, prefatory note.</note>
      <note type="additional physical form">Also issued online.</note>
      <note>List of bulletins, with contents of each, and author and subject index may be found in "Catalogue and index of the publications of the Hayden, King, Powell, and Wheeler surveys ... by L.F. Schmeckebier. 1904." (U.S. Geological survey. Bulletin no. 222).</note>

      <titleInfo>
         <nonSort xml:space="preserve">The  </nonSort>
         <title>four fundamental concepts of psycho-analysis</title>
      </titleInfo>
      <titleInfo nameTitleGroup="1" type="uniform">
         <title>Quatre concepts fondamentaux de la psychanalyse. English</title>
      </titleInfo>
      <name nameTitleGroup="1" type="personal" usage="primary">
         <namePart>Lacan, Jacques</namePart>
         <namePart type="date">1901-1981</namePart>
         <role>
            <roleTerm type="text">creator</roleTerm>
         </role>
      </name>
      <typeOfResource>text</typeOfResource>
      <genre authority="2">Essays.</genre>
      <originInfo>
         <place>
            <placeTerm authority="marccountry" type="code">nyu</placeTerm>
            <placeTerm authority="marccountry" type="text">New York (State)</placeTerm>
         </place>
         <place>
            <placeTerm type="text">New York</placeTerm>
         </place>
         <publisher>Norton</publisher>
         <dateIssued>1978</dateIssued>
         <edition>1st American ed.</edition>
         <issuance>monographic</issuance>
      </originInfo>
      <language>
         <languageTerm authority="iso639-2b" type="code">eng</languageTerm>
         <languageTerm authority="iso639-2b" type="text">English</languageTerm>
      </language>
      <language>
         <languageTerm authority="iso639-2b" type="code">fre</languageTerm>
      </language>
      <physicalDescription>
         <form authority="marcform">print</form>
         <extent>xi, 290 p. ; 22 cm.</extent>
      </physicalDescription>
      <abstract type="Summary">Probes the relationship between psychoanalysis and science and religion as well as defining the unconscious, the repetition, the transference, and the drive as the underlying concepts of psycho-analysis.</abstract>
      <tableOfContents>Preface to the English-language edition -- Editor's note -- 1. Excommunication -- THE UNCONSCIOUS AND REPETITION -- 2. The Freudian unconscious and ours -- 3. Of the subject of certainty -- 4. Of the network of signifiers -- 5. Tuche and Automaton -- OF THE GAZE AS Objet Petit a -- 6. The split between the eye and the gaze -- 7. Anamorphosis -- 8. The line and light -- 9. What is a picture? -- THE TRANSFERENCE AND THE DRIVE -- 10. Presence of the analyst -- 11. Analysis and truth or the closure of the unconscious -- 12. Sexuality in the defiles of the signifier -- 13. The deconstruction of the drive -- 14. The partial drive and its circuit -- 15. From love to the libido -- THE FIELD OF THE OTHER AND BACK TO THE TRANSFERENCE -- 16. The subject and the other: alienation -- 17. The subject and the other: aphanisis -- 18. Of the subject who is supposed to know, of the first dyad and of the good -- 19. From interpretation to the transference -- TO CONCLUDE -- 20. In you more than you -- Translator's note -- Index.</tableOfContents>
      <note type="statement of responsibility">Jacques Lacan ; edited by Jacques-Alain Miller ; translated from the French by Alan Sheridan.</note>
      <note>Translation of Les quatre concepts fondamentaux de la psychanalyse, originally published as v. 11 of the author's Le séminaire de Jacques Lacan.</note>

      <titleInfo>
         <nonSort xml:space="preserve">The  </nonSort>
         <title>age of the Reformation</title>
      </titleInfo>
      <name nameTitleGroup="1" type="personal" usage="primary">
         <namePart>Bainton, Roland Herbert</namePart>
         <namePart type="date">1894-1984</namePart>
         <role>
            <roleTerm type="text">creator</roleTerm>
         </role>
      </name>
      <typeOfResource>text</typeOfResource>
      <genre authority="marcgt">bibliography</genre>
      <genre authority="fast">Sources.</genre>
      <genre authority="fast">Sources.</genre>
      <originInfo>
         <place>
            <placeTerm authority="marccountry" type="code">flu</placeTerm>
            <placeTerm authority="marccountry" type="text">Florida</placeTerm>
         </place>
         <place>
            <placeTerm type="text">Malabar, Fla</placeTerm>
         </place>
         <publisher>R.E. Krieger Pub. Co.</publisher>
         <dateIssued>1984, c1956</dateIssued>
         <dateIssued encoding="marc">1984</dateIssued>
         <issuance>monographic</issuance>
      </originInfo>
      <language>
         <languageTerm authority="iso639-2b" type="code">eng</languageTerm>
         <languageTerm authority="iso639-2b" type="text">English</languageTerm>
      </language>
      <physicalDescription>
         <form authority="marcform">print</form>
         <extent>191 p. ; 19 cm.</extent>
      </physicalDescription>
      <abstract type="Summary">With the aid of over sixty important sources, most of them translated and abridged by the author, this brief history brings an age of upheaval into sharp focus. It shows succinctly how a compelling ideology, the Christian faith, shaped the history of the Reformation. The religious revolution of the sixteenth century shattered an ecclesiastical structure and quickened a universal faith. The Christian heritage which the Reformation revitalized and transmitted to our time is still the source of Western man's ability to talk in terms of a universal justice, humanity, and the rights of man.</abstract>
      <tableOfContents>The outbreak of the Lutheran revolt -- The reformed churches : Zwingli and the Anabaptists -- Calvinism -- Scandinavia and the British Isles -- The Catholic Reformation -- Persecution, rebellion, war, and liberty -- The effects of the reformation -- Luther's early development -- The indulgence controversy and Luther's proposals for practical reform -- Luther's revision of the sacraments -- Luther and the Saxon radicals -- The reformed churches : Zwingli and the Anabaptists -- The reformed churches : Calvinism -- The Anglican church established -- The Catholic reformation -- Confessions of faith -- Edicts affecting religion -- THe right of rebellion -- Persecution and liberty.</tableOfContents>
      <note type="statement of responsibility">Roland H. Bainton.</note>
      <note>"An Anvil original."</note>
      <note>Reprint. Originally published: Princeton, N.J. : Van Nostrand, 1956.</note>
      <note>Includes index.</note>
      <note type="bibliography">Bibliography: p. 186-188.</note>

      <physicalDescription>
         <form authority="marcform">print</form>
         <extent>6 v. : ill., plates (some folded), maps (some folded) ; 23 cm.</extent>
      </physicalDescription>
      <note type="statement of responsibility">Department of the Interior.</note>
      <note type="date/sequential designation">No. 1-2 (1874); second ser. [vol. 1], no. 1 (1875)-v. 6, no. 3 (1882).</note>
      <note>"F.V. Hayden, U.S. Geologist-in-charge."</note>
      <note type="numbering">"The first and second bulletins, which appeared in 1874, are separately paged pamphlets ... constituting a 'First Series' of the publication. Bulletins which appeared in 1875, being those of a 'Second series' and six in number, are continuously paged. With no. 6 were issued title, contents, index, &amp; c., for all the numbers of both 'series' which had then appeared; the design being that these should together constitute volume I, in order that the inconvenient distinction of 'series' might be dropped." Cf. v. 6, prefatory note.</note>
      <note type="additional physical form">Also issued online.</note>
      <note>List of bulletins, with contents of each, and author and subject index may be found in "Catalogue and index of the publications of the Hayden, King, Powell, and Wheeler surveys ... by L.F. Schmeckebier. 1904." (U.S. Geological survey. Bulletin no. 222).</note>

      <titleInfo>
         <nonSort xml:space="preserve">The  </nonSort>
         <title>four fundamental concepts of psycho-analysis</title>
      </titleInfo>
      <titleInfo nameTitleGroup="1" type="uniform">
         <title>Quatre concepts fondamentaux de la psychanalyse. English</title>
      </titleInfo>
      <name nameTitleGroup="1" type="personal" usage="primary">
         <namePart>Lacan, Jacques</namePart>
         <namePart type="date">1901-1981</namePart>

         <extent>xi, 290 p. ; 22 cm.</extent>
      </physicalDescription>
      <abstract type="Summary">Probes the relationship between psychoanalysis and science and religion as well as defining the unconscious, the repetition, the transference, and the drive as the underlying concepts of psycho-analysis.</abstract>
      <tableOfContents>Preface to the English-language edition -- Editor's note -- 1. Excommunication -- THE UNCONSCIOUS AND REPETITION -- 2. The Freudian unconscious and ours -- 3. Of the subject of certainty -- 4. Of the network of signifiers -- 5. Tuche and Automaton -- OF THE GAZE AS Objet Petit a -- 6. The split between the eye and the gaze -- 7. Anamorphosis -- 8. The line and light -- 9. What is a picture? -- THE TRANSFERENCE AND THE DRIVE -- 10. Presence of the analyst -- 11. Analysis and truth or the closure of the unconscious -- 12. Sexuality in the defiles of the signifier -- 13. The deconstruction of the drive -- 14. The partial drive and its circuit -- 15. From love to the libido -- THE FIELD OF THE OTHER AND BACK TO THE TRANSFERENCE -- 16. The subject and the other: alienation -- 17. The subject and the other: aphanisis -- 18. Of the subject who is supposed to know, of the first dyad and of the good -- 19. From interpretation to the transference -- TO CONCLUDE -- 20. In you more than you -- Translator's note -- Index.</tableOfContents>
      <note type="statement of responsibility">Jacques Lacan ; edited by Jacques-Alain Miller ; translated from the French by Alan Sheridan.</note>
      <note>Translation of Les quatre concepts fondamentaux de la psychanalyse, originally published as v. 11 of the author's Le séminaire de Jacques Lacan.</note>
      <note>Includes index.</note>

   <mods xmlns:mods="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3"
         xmlns:marc="http://www.loc.gov/MARC21/slim"
         xmlns:urlinfo="http://lib.harvard.edu/urlinfo"
         xmlns:countries="info:lc/xmlns/codelist-v1"
         xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
         xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">
      <titleInfo>
         <nonSort xml:space="preserve">The  </nonSort>
         <title>age of the Reformation</title>
      </titleInfo>
      <name nameTitleGroup="1" type="personal" usage="primary">
         <namePart>Bainton, Roland Herbert</namePart>
         <namePart type="date">1894-1984</namePart>
         <role>
            <roleTerm type="text">creator</roleTerm>
         </role>
      </name>
      <typeOfResource>text</typeOfResource>
      <genre authority="marcgt">bibliography</genre>
      <genre authority="fast">Sources.</genre>
      <genre authority="fast">Sources.</genre>
      <originInfo>
         <place>
            <placeTerm authority="marccountry" type="code">flu</placeTerm>
            <placeTerm authority="marccountry" type="text">Florida</placeTerm>
         </place>
         <place>
            <placeTerm type="text">Malabar, Fla</placeTerm>
         </place>
         <publisher>R.E. Krieger Pub. Co.</publisher>
         <dateIssued>1984, c1956</dateIssued>
         <dateIssued encoding="marc">1984</dateIssued>
         <issuance>monographic</issuance>
      </originInfo>
      <language>
         <languageTerm authority="iso639-2b" type="code">eng</languageTerm>
         <languageTerm authority="iso639-2b" type="text">English</languageTerm>
      </language>
      <physicalDescription>
         <form authority="marcform">print</form>
         <extent>191 p. ; 19 cm.</extent>
      </physicalDescription>
      <abstract type="Summary">With the aid of over sixty important sources, most of them translated and abridged by the author, this brief history brings an age of upheaval into sharp focus. It shows succinctly how a compelling ideology, the Christian faith, shaped the history of the Reformation. The religious revolution of the sixteenth century shattered an ecclesiastical structure and quickened a universal faith. The Christian heritage which the Reformation revitalized and transmitted to our time is still the source of Western man's ability to talk in terms of a universal justice, humanity, and the rights of man.</abstract>
      <tableOfContents>The outbreak of the Lutheran revolt -- The reformed churches : Zwingli and the Anabaptists -- Calvinism -- Scandinavia and the British Isles -- The Catholic Reformation -- Persecution, rebellion, war, and liberty -- The effects of the reformation -- Luther's early development -- The indulgence controversy and Luther's proposals for practical reform -- Luther's revision of the sacraments -- Luther and the Saxon radicals -- The reformed churches : Zwingli and the Anabaptists -- The reformed churches : Calvinism -- The Anglican church established -- The Catholic reformation -- Confessions of faith -- Edicts affecting religion -- THe right of rebellion -- Persecution and liberty.</tableOfContents>
      <note type="statement of responsibility">Roland H. Bainton.</note>
      <note>"An Anvil original."</note>
      <note>Reprint. Originally published: Princeton, N.J. : Van Nostrand, 1956.</note>
      <note>Includes index.</note>
      <note type="bibliography">Bibliography: p. 186-188.</note>
      <subject>
         <geographicCode authority="marcgac">e------</geographicCode>
      </subject>
      <subject authority="lcsh">
         <topic>Reformation</topic>
      </subject>
      <subject authority="lcsh">
         <topic>Reformation</topic>
         <topic>Sources</topic>
      </subject>
      <classification authority="lcc">BR305.2 .B295 1984</classification>

      <titleInfo>
         <title>Jeffers petroglyphs walking tour</title>
